column2: Which of these is necessary condition for automatic type conversion in Java?
column3: a) The destination type is smaller than source type
column4: b) The destination type is larger than source type.
column5: c) The destination type can be larger or smaller than source type.

column4: b) * operator has converted b * 50 into int  which can not be converted to byte without casting.

column2: If an expression contains double int float long then whole expression will promoted into which of these data types?

column3: a) Floating-point value assigned to an integer type.
column4: b) Integer value assigned to floating type.
column5: c) Floating-point value assigned to an Floating type.
column6: d) Integer value assigned to floating type.

column3: a) Generics make code more fast.
column4: b) Generics make code more optimised and readable.
column5: c) Generics add stability to your code by making more of your bugs detectable at compile time.
column6: d) Generics add stability to your code by making more of your bugs detectable at run time.

column2: Which of these type parameters is used for a generic class to return and accept any type of object?

Which of these selection statements test only for equality?
Which of the following is incorrect statement regarding the use of generics and parameterized types in Java?
column3: a) Generics provide type safety by shifting more type checking responsibilities to the compiler.
column4: b) Generics and parameterized types eliminate the need for down casts when using Java Collections.
column5: c) When designing your own collections class (say a linked list) generics and parameterized types allow you to achieve type safety with just a single class definition as opposed to defining multiple classes.
